'''David Threlfall''' (born 12 October 1953) is an English stage, film and television [[actor]] and [[television director|director]] best known for playing [[Frank Gallagher (Shameless)|Frank Gallagher]] in [[Channel 4]]'s [[Manchester]]-based drama series ''[[Shameless]]''. He has also directed several episodes of the show.
==Early life== The son of a plumber, Tommy Threlfall and his wife, he was born in [[Burnage]], [[Manchester]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/david-threlfall-frank-in-more-than-one-sense-431004.html|title=David Threlfall: Frank, in more than one sense|last=Jury |first=Louise|work=[[The Independent]] |location=UK |date=6 January 2007 |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref> His introduction to drama came from school and two [[English language|English]] teachers, at Wilbraham High School, where he was a contemporary of the younger Lorraine Ashbourne. Encouragement from those teachers led to him playing the male lead in a four performance school production of Ann Jellicoe's "Rising Generation" in 1971. December that year saw him playing John Proctor in a school production of ''[[The Crucible]]'' and then to his getting involved with Manchester Youth Theatre. He went to art college in [[Sheffield]], now [[Sheffield Hallam University]], but only stayed for a year. A few months of labouring and thinking followed. Then, having consulted a magazine in a [[public library]] which listed drama colleges, Threlfall successfully applied to Manchester Polytechnic School of Drama. By graduation, he had an audition with [[Mike Leigh]].
Threlfall has been a keen supporter of [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] since childhood.<ref>[http://fourfourtwo.com/interviews/celebrityfans/51/article.aspx Celebrity fans: David Threlfall], ''FourFourTwo.com''</ref>
==Career== Threlfall graduated from [[The Manchester Metropolitan School of Theatre]]. He has notched up a wide range of film and television credits since his 1974 acting debut in the [[Play for Today]] version of the film ''[[Scum (film)|Scum]]'' as the eloquent Archer.<ref name="Ind070107">Pryor, Cathy, [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/david-threlfall-being-frank-and-shameless-431142.html David Threlfall: Being Frank and Shameless], ''Independent.co.uk'', 7 January 2007</ref> Television appearances include Trevor in [[Mike Leigh]]'s 1977 made-for-TV film ''[[Kiss of Death (1977 made-for-TV film)|Kiss of Death]]'', Leslie Titmuss in ''[[Paradise Postponed]]'', Edgar in the 1984 [[Granada Television]] production of ''[[King Lear]]'' opposite [[Sir Laurence Olivier]] in the title role. He also had regular roles in the [[situation comedy|situation comedies]] ''[[Nightingales]]'' and ''[[Men of the World]]'', and guest appearances in dramas such as ''[[Cutting It]]'', ''[[The Knock]]'', ''[[CI5: The New Professionals]]'' and ''[[Spooks]]''. He played [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] in ''Diana: Her True Story'' in 1993 and his father [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]] in the 2005 drama ''[[The Queen's Sister]]''. David currently plays the key character of [[Frank Gallagher]] in [[Paul Abbott]]'s ''[[Shameless]]''. Shown on [[Channel 4]] since its first series in 2004, the ongoing show about the residents of a fictional Manchester housing estate is now in its eighth series, shown in 2011.
He also played the role of [[Friedrich Kritzinger]] in the BBC/HBO drama ''[[Conspiracy (2001 film)|Conspiracy]]'', a dramatisation of the [[Wannsee Conference]]. In 2006, he played the domineering husband of wartime diarist [[Nella Last]], in the TV drama ''[[Housewife, 49]]''
Film credits include [[John le CarrÃ©]]'s ''[[The Russia House]]'', ''[[Patriot Games (film)|Patriot Games]]'', ''[[Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World]]'', ''[[Elizabeth: The Golden Age]]'', alongside [[Cate Blanchett]], and ''[[Nowhere Boy]]'' in which he took the part of [[John Lennon]]'s [[George Toogood Smith|Uncle George]].
He also had a small role in the 2006 film ''[[Alien Autopsy]]'', and played the character Martin Blower in the 2007 film ''[[Hot Fuzz]]'', acting alongside [[Simon Pegg]] and [[Nick Frost]]. He recently starred in an episode of ''The Whistle Blowers''.
He starred as the lead role in the fourth episode of the BBC Documentary-Drama series ''[[Ancient Rome: The Rise and Fall of an Empire]]'' as the Emperor [[Constantine I]].
He voiced the detective Paolo Baldi in [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Baldi (radio)|Baldi]]''.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/drama/radio/baldi4.shtml BALDI SERIES 4], ''BBC.co.uk''</ref> He also read [[Joseph Conrad]]'s ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' for a radio adaptation.
In 1980 he played Smike in the eight-hour stage version of ''[[The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby (play)|The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby]]'' for the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] in both London and New York.
Other notable stage performances include ''[[Riddley Walker]]'', ''[[Oedipus]]'', ''[[Macbeth]]'' and ''[[Peer Gynt]]'' at the [[Royal Exchange Theatre]], [[Manchester]], Bolingbroke in ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' and Orgon in ''[[Tartuffe]]'' at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] in London.
Threlfall played Jack in ''When the Whales Came'' (1989), opposite [[Paul Scofield]] and [[Helen Mirren]].
In 2010, he appeared as a guest on ''[[Have I Got News for You]]''.

==Personal life== Threlfall has been married to [[Bosnians|Bosnian]] actress [[Brana Bajic]] since 1995.<ref name="St060504">Elkin, Susan, [http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/feature.php/2012 Art of the shapeshifter â David Threlfall], ''TheStage.co.uk'', 6 May 2004</ref> They met in 1994, whilst working on ''The Count of Monte Cristo'' at the Royal Exchange Theatre in Manchester.<ref name="St060504"/>
David admits that despite his ''Shameless'' character being a chain smoker, in real life he is a non-smoker who has a dislike for nicotine.<ref>[http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2007/01/05/we-re-so-shameless-115875-18393942/ We're so shameless]</ref>
His niece is Jazz singer Kate Threlfall.<ref>[http://www.katethrelfall.com/ Kate Threlfall Official Site]</ref>
